docs.lead_paragraph: Africans dominated the world cross-country championships yesterday in Belfast, Northern Ireland, winning seven of the nine individual medals. Ethiopia's Gete Wami won the senior women's five-mile race in 28 minutes. She was followed by her teammate Merima Denboba and Britain's Paula Radcliffe.
docs.abstract: Africans win 7 of 9 individual medals at world cross-country championships in Belfast, Northern Ireland; Gete Wami of Ethiopia wins senior women's five-mile race, and Benjamin Limo of Kenya takes senior men's 2.6-mile event (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN the moment of clash finally arrives, when two minds go one-on-one at the line of scrimmage, it is easy to imagine debate as a contact sport. The Grover Cleveland High School team had seemed up for its second match in this season's Lincoln-Douglas Debates two weeks ago, and when the coin toss gave it the negative position on the topic, ''Resolved: That affirmative action in American society today is consistent with equality of opportunity,'' they pumped fists. Elizabeth Vega hugged Jessica Leal.

headline.main: Clash Struggle: Debaters Go Toe to Toe

docs.abstract: Robert Lipsyte Coping column describes combative attitude of high school teams participating in recent Lincoln-Douglas Debates at Chase Manhattan Bank, NYC; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Are children harmed by divorce? So far the public debate has done more to confuse than enlighten, says Andrew Cherlin, the president of the Population Association of America. Here are excerpts from the presidential address he delivered yesterday at the group's annual meeting in New York City. Demographers study things that are close to people's lives: population growth, immigration, adolescent pregnancy and childbearing, racial segregation, the labor market, gender equity -- and on and on. As a result, the broader public often pays attention to our findings.

headline.main: Caroming Between Extremes, Social Scientists Can Overlook Reality

docs.abstract: Excerpt from speech by Andrew Cherlin, president of Population Assn of America, discussing widely varying theories about effects of divorce on children; warns colleagues that tendency to advance extreme arguments is built into scientific method that most demographers, including himself, attempt to follow; quotes Albert Einstein's advice that everything 'should be made as simple as possible, but not simpler' (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Suit! Anger! Agreement! In what union officials called a victory for directors' rights, the Society of Stage Directors and Choreographers said it had completed an out-of-court settlement with a theater in Florida over its production of ''Love! Valour! Compassion!'' The union said the theater had used the work of Joe Mantello, the play's director on Broadway, without his permission. The settlement, between the union and the Caldwell Theater Company of Boca Raton, ends a three-year legal battle. As part of the agreement, Mr. Mantello is to receive about $7,000 as well as a written acknowledgment that the theater had inadvertently used his work without his permission.
docs.abstract: On Stage and Off column; Society of Stage Directors and Choreographers announces out-of-court settlement with Caldwell Theater Company in Boca Raton, Florida, over use of director Joe Mantello's staging without his permission; suit involved production of Love! Valour! Compassion!; You're a Good Man, Charlie Brown drops some evening performances and adds more weekend matinees to bring in more young people; Julie Kavner replaces Mo Gaffney, who is pregnant, in The Mineola Twins; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: For the third time, the State Senate passed a bill today outlawing a form of abortion, continuing a national debate over the procedure, which opponents call partial-birth abortion. Though the Assembly is deeply divided over the issue, people close to Speaker Sheldon Silver, a Manhattan Democrat, said it was likely that he would prevent the bill from coming to a vote in that house, as he has in years past. Advocates of the ban believe it would win passage in the Assembly.

headline.main: State Senate Again Passes Ban on a Type Of Abortion

docs.abstract: New York State Senate, for third time, passes bill outlawing form of abortion, continuing national debate over procedure, which opponents call partial-birth abortion (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Canadian scientists report today in a study that women who were exposed to organic solvents like phenol, xylene and acetone during pregnancy had a greatly increased chance of having a baby with a birth defect. But leading experts on birth defects said the study had serious methodological problems. They said they feared that the paper, published today in the Journal of the American Medical Association, would needlessly frighten pregnant women.

headline.main: A Study Finds Link Between Birth Defects And Solvents

docs.abstract: Canadian study finds that women who were exposed to organic solvents like phenol, xylene and acetone during pregnancy had greatly increased chance of having baby with birth defect; Drs Sohail Khattak and Gideon Koren of Hospital for Sick Children in Toronto led research; experts on birth defects say study has serious methodological problems (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The sniper killing of Dr. Barnett Slepian has inspired leaders on both sides of the abortion debate to work together to remedy social ills that lead to abortions, a coalition of religious and community leaders said today. A month before abortion opponents and abortion rights supporters are expected to clash during a weeklong anti-abortion campaign in Buffalo, the coalition urged tolerance and respect for opposing viewpoints.

headline.main: In Buffalo, Seeking Common Ground on Abortion

docs.abstract: Coalition of religious and community leaders in Buffalo says sniper killing of Dr Barnett Slepian has inspired leaders on both sides of abortion debate to work together to remedy social ills that lead to abortions (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Pragmatists within the Republican Party have come to regard the abortion issue as an albatross that could ruin their chances of maintaining control of Congress and winning the Presidency in 2000. While all of the party's declared Presidential candidates describe themselves as pro-life, the real issues debate among them has not been over how to outlaw abortion, but how to keep it from playing a central part in the upcoming campaign. Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, the leading Republican Presidential hopeful, does not talk about ending the right to abortion, but about reducing the number of abortions by encouraging adoption and requiring that minors seeking abortions obtain parental consent. Mr. Bush also weaves the abortion issue into a larger ''reverence for life'' agenda that includes everything from combatting drunken driving to promoting sexual abstinence. It is far more appealing than the old anti-abortion rhetoric, which frequently sounded harsh and judgmental.
docs.abstract: Editorial contends that Republican Party's anti-abortion pragmatists want to leave pro-life plank in their party platform intact, and then duck issue through Presidential campaign; maintains that Gov George E Pataki has made that more difficult with his recent bold call for elimination of plank; praises Pataki for tackling issue in way that makes other moderates look evasive by comparison
